> But wouldn't that break up the network's knowledge of what happened >in
=
> previous rounds? Or would the turn also have an input that says what
> ha=
ppened preflop and on the flop?
>

The latter, as I described in either my =
original or second post on
this thread.  The point of having separate netwo=
rks is to be able to
have a fixed number of inputs, which wouldn't be possi=
ble otherwise
due to variations in the betting rounds and the number of car=
ds on the
board.

Think about it like this: you're on the flop and want to =
pass the
information about preflop betting and the 3 community cards on the=

board.  If you have 1 network that is supposed to deal with the turn
and r=
iver as well as the preflop/flop play, you will have to have some
nodes for=
 the turn and river community cards (ignoring betting even).
 Since you are=
 not on those rounds, you can either put in some sort of
negative value (-1=
 probably) and hope the network learns that -1 means
no card; or you can ha=
ve a 2nd node for each card node and have 0
represent "no card" and 1 repre=
sent "is a card", and expect the
network to learn the association there.  H=
owever, if you have a
separate network for the flop, you KNOW you need 3 fl=
op card nodes and
don't have to worry about anything else.

An analogous ar=
gument applies for betting information about each
round.  You can use bet l=
evel, aggressor, and position to fully
describe a previous round of betting=
 (in a 2 person game, which is
what we're trying to do in the AAAI competit=
ion).  This provides a
fixed size of 3*round for betting information.  It's=
 pretty clever and
elegant, I think. :)

> 
> I think that is a really good=
 idea. Sounds like there are a few 
> interested
> and talented people.
> 
=

I am really excited about the idea of parallelizing NEAT as a first
step, =
actually.  The downside here might be that we would be cutting
it close for=
 the competition deadline.  However, I think we can work
on the two at the =
same time by using a serial implementation and then
later converting it ove=
r (which should be seamless).

The first step for the poker code would prob=
ably be to get a
simulation engine that we can all agree is sufficient.  Mo=
st of my
code is psuedo-windows proprietary.  It was written with the idea =
of
scraping a poker table's screen and composing a game state from that,
an=
d I didn't lay out the headers very well, so there's a couple of
things tha=
t won't compile on linux.  However, I used only STL
containers, so the logi=
c should compile fine.  If you guys wanted to
use mine (at least as a quick=
 and dirty implementation), I'll see if I
can refactor the code this weeken=
d and upload it somewhere.  I'd
certainly be open to a different (likely be=
tter) engine if there's one
freely available in C++.  Either way, please le=
t me know.


Wesley
